an
Wikipedia entries on cardiovascular diseases lack accuracy, according to an article in BMJ Open
I just want to let you know about a recently published article in the journal BMJ Open that tried to "evaluate accuracy of content and readability level of English Wikipedia articles on cardiovascular diseases": ite journal| authors = Azer SA, AlSwaidan NM, Alshwairikh LA, AlShammari JM | url = http://bmjopen.bmj.com/content/5/10/e008187.full | title = Accuracy and readability of cardiovascular entries on Wikipedia: are they reliable learning resources for medical students? | year = 2015 | journal = BMJ Open | volume = 5 | pages = e008187 | doi = 10.1136/bmjopen-2015-008187 --ser:Sentausa|sentausa (ser talk:Sentausa|talk) 12:32, 10 October 2015 (UTC) The four topics rated "poor": cute pericarditis, ngina pectoris, rosthetic heart valves, ulmonic regurgitation. ser:KateWishing|KateWishing (ser talk:KateWishing|talk) 13:11, 10 October 2015 (UTC) The main problem highlighted under the "accuracy" component of the study is incompleteness. Falsehoods don't seem to be an issue. "The highest score was 45 for the article on deep vein thrombosis while the lowest was 28 for the article on acute pericarditis. The 47 Wikipedia articles had a median score=33, IQR=6—the highest possible score was 50. Out of the 47 entries, 4 (8.5%) articles scored 40 or higher, described as Good as per our cut-off system, 39 (83%) articles scored 30 to 39, described as Moderate as per our cut-off system and 4 (8.5%) scored less than 30, described as Poor as per our cut-off system. We did not observe vandalism of the 47 entries during the conduction of the study." (My bolding.) ser:Biosthmors had shepherded eep vein thrombosis through Wikipedia's internal peer review process twice in 2012 (the year before the study date). --ser:Anthonyhcole|Anthonyhcole (ser talk:Anthonyhcole|talk · pecial:Contributions/Anthonyhcole|contribs · pecial:EmailUser/Anthonyhcole|email) 14:11, 10 October 2015 (UTC)
*for the record..The search was conducted on the 6 of October 2013 by three evaluators independently, and entries identified were printed out on the same day[http://bmjopen.bmj.com/content/5/10/e008187.full]--ser:Ozzie10aaaa|Ozzie10aaaa (ser talk:Ozzie10aaaa|talk) 23:45, 10 October 2015 (UTC) I have done a fair bit of work on the leads of many of these articles in the last year or two. ser:Doc James|Doc James (ser talk:Doc James|talk · pecial:Contributions/Doc James|contribs · pecial:EmailUser/Doc James|email) 16:59, 11 October 2015 (UTC) Thanks ser:Anthonyhcole for [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Wikipedia_talk:WikiProject_Medicine&diff=next&oldid=685053934 that] attempted notification. (For whatever reason, I did not receive a notification from you that day. I'll ask why at ikipedia talk:Notifications.) It was nice to see my most extensive medical contribution positively reviewed (however briefly) in a medical journal. I'm glad that it was picked as an article to review. ser:Biosthmors|Biosthmors (ser talk:Biosthmors|talk) pls ikipedia:Notifications#Features|notify me (i.e. {{emplate:U|U}}) while signing a reply, thx 21:23, 15 October 2015 (UTC) No Worries. You mentioned back then that you might put it through FA. It looks like it's a worthy candidate, ser:Biosthmors|Biosthmors. (Did that ping work?) --ser:Anthonyhcole|Anthonyhcole (ser talk:Anthonyhcole|talk · pecial:Contributions/Anthonyhcole|contribs · pecial:EmailUser/Anthonyhcole|email) 01:27, 16 October 2015 (UTC) That one did, thanks. I don't plan on getting it up to FA at the moment. But that might change depending upon what opportunities it might open up. =) If deep vein thrombosis was brought up at FA level, were you thinking about an expert peer review by BMJ perhaps? That would be cool, but beyond that, I think it would be more exciting if we could get the article actually published in BMJ Open. I see that "All BMJ Open articles are licensed using either Creative Commons Attribution (CC BY) or Attribution Non-Commercial (CC BY-NC) licence."[http://bmjopen.bmj.com/site/about/] Does that mean there is a licensing incompatibility between Wikipedia and BMJ Open? This has been explained to me in the past, I'm sure. I see Wikipedia is CC BY-SA. If there is an incompatibility, then it still seems there is another possible way to get the article published under a new license: the main author(s) could re-license the content if necessary after demonstrating that they alone deserve to be recognized as authors (there is a tool that would be helpful, but I forgot its name). Anyhow, any ideas here ser:Anthonyhcole|Anthonyhcole? Thanks. ser:Biosthmors|Biosthmors (ser talk:Biosthmors|talk) pls ikipedia:Notifications#Features|notify me (i.e. {{emplate:U|U}}) while signing a reply, thx 13:46, 17 October 2015 (UTC) So the share alike (SA)[http://oaspa.org/why-cc-by/] portion would have to be dropped before an open access journal is likely to publish it, it appears. ser:Biosthmors|Biosthmors (ser talk:Biosthmors|talk) pls ikipedia:Notifications#Features|notify me (i.e. {{emplate:U|U}}) while signing a reply, thx 13:55, 17 October 2015 (UTC) It appears that this publication might have caused a page view spike at the DVT article, from 1,000 (or under) to over 12,000 page views in one day. The article was published on Oct. 6, which corresponds with the spike, which was sustained over several days.[http://stats.grok.se/en/latest/Deep_vein_thrombosis] That's impressive to me if that was the cause. ser:Biosthmors|Biosthmors (ser talk:Biosthmors|talk) pls ikipedia:Notifications#Features|notify me (i.e. {{emplate:U|U}}) while signing a reply, thx 01:47, 18 October 2015 (UTC) I'm pretty sure we can't publish Wikipedia articles under BMJ Open's current license. Yes, if you bring DVT up to P:FA|FA, I'll submit it to BMJ for review. Just to be clear, BMJ are recruiting the best qualified reviewers they can lay their hands on for this project. That is, they're choosing from the same pool of reviewers they would use for any of their journals (including BMJ Open) but for us they're approaching only the best in that pool. They're taking the integrity of this review process very seriously. We expect that Reliable Wikipedia (or whatever we end up calling it) will quickly gain a deserved reputation for excellence and rock-solid reliability, second to none. My point is, while it would definitely be cool to have the article published in BMJ Open (the journal that published the criticism), it'll be even cooler to have it published in Reliable Wikipedia. I know how absurd it sounds just now but this is easily achievable and where this is going: researchers will cite the reliable version of eep vein thrombosis in peer-reviewed articles, professors will refer their students to it, and authors will cut and paste slabs of it into textbook chapters with attribution. And you'll add it to the top of your list of publications when applying for academic advancement or tenure. --ser:Anthonyhcole|Anthonyhcole (ser talk:Anthonyhcole|talk · pecial:Contributions/Anthonyhcole|contribs · pecial:EmailUser/Anthonyhcole|email) 05:15, 18 October 2015 (UTC) I'm dubious about the claim that researchers will cite the reliable any version of a Wikipedia article in many peer-reviewed articles. Don't most journals have a rule that requires only primary sources to be cited? ser:WhatamIdoing|WhatamIdoing (ser talk:WhatamIdoing|talk) 16:32, 19 October 2015 (UTC) I'm not sure about a rule, but the usual expectation is that you'll cite the original research rather than a secondary or tertiary source when you're referring to prior research. ser:soupvector touches on this in his Wikiconference talk I linked to in the thread above this. I wouldn't expect an article in a peer-reviewed journal to cite reviewed versions of Wikipedia articles for anything but definitions, general principles, etc. As for my point about slabs of a Wikipedia appearing in textbooks - that will only happen if the publisher allows a part of the book to conform with our Creative Commons license - so it will be rare and will more likely be a quote. Really, I'm just trying to convey the nature of the paradigm shift we're trying to catalyse here. --ser:Anthonyhcole|Anthonyhcole (ser talk:Anthonyhcole|talk · pecial:Contributions/Anthonyhcole|contribs · pecial:EmailUser/Anthonyhcole|email) 02:07, 20 October 2015 (UTC) Agree - I also want this shift to occur, but that won't make it happen. There's a big gap in credibility, currently, between BMJ Open (already listed in MEDLINE and having an ISI Impact Factor of just over 2) and Reliable Wikipedia (or whatever name it gets, still "vaporware"). The former could be cited as a reliable source in a peer-reviewed journal and in one's academic CV to support promotion etc; the latter might someday serve those purposes, but not now or soon. Nonetheless, I am hopeful but I'm not sure what revenue will support the editorial staff (not talking about the volunteer peer reviewers - I'm talking about the salaried folks who do all the other stuff that make a journal function reliably). — ser:soupvector|soupvector (ser_talk:soupvector|talk) 02:20, 20 October 2015 (UTC) I'm expecting Wikimedia to host the reviewed articles, and to help us volunteers (at least in the beginning) to transform the reviewed version into a nice, journal-like presentation. I'll ask for BMJ's help with that too. Once we have a system in place, copying a reviewed version from the article's history to the "journal space" should be a fairly streamlined process. I expect arranging for PubMed indexing and doi allocation will be fairly straightforward, too, after the first few times. If it becomes too onerous for a volunteer to keep on top of, I'm confident we'll get funding to employ someone. While BMJ is willing to do the other stuff - basically, attracting the highest quality reviewers to the job for free - I don't think there is any need for a lot of funding. They may tire of it, at which point we'll look elsewhere. Or they may invite their peers at other specialiist journals to shoulder some of the load. I'm looking forward to BMJ's thoughts once they and we get to know each other and how this all works a bit better.
Regarding the credibility of BMJ-reviewed versions of Wikipedia articles, they will be highly credible. The task will be to convey that fact to the public and academy. I'm assuming we'll do a good job of that. If we don't, all of this is pretty much a waste of time. Lila at the WMF realises that and so do Peter and Fiona at BMJ. None of us has time to waste. --ser:Anthonyhcole|Anthonyhcole (ser talk:Anthonyhcole|talk · pecial:Contributions/Anthonyhcole|contribs · pecial:EmailUser/Anthonyhcole|email) 09:43, 20 October 2015 (UTC) I don't think there is precedent for any web site becoming academically credible (citable for promotion or scholarly publication) by virtue of being peer reviewed by a credible journal. I'm not trying to discourage - just cautioning that a plan without precedent has unclear risk. — ser:soupvector|soupvector (ser_talk:soupvector|talk) 22:11, 20 October 2015 (UTC) Yes, agreed, this is a new thing; and we're being very slow and cautious in our approach. --ser:Anthonyhcole|Anthonyhcole (ser talk:Anthonyhcole|talk · pecial:Contributions/Anthonyhcole|contribs · pecial:EmailUser/Anthonyhcole|email) 04:10, 23 October 2015 (UTC)
cientific American source/prevalence of domestic violence data at the omestic violence article
Opinions are needed on the following matter: alk:Domestic violence#Should the Scientific American "rates of domestic violence are roughly equal between men and women" material be included? A P:Permalink for it is [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Talk:Domestic_violence&oldid=687083173#Should_the_Scientific_American_.22rates_of_domestic_violence_are_roughly_equal_between_men_and_women.22_material_be_included.3F here]. ser:Flyer22|Flyer22 (ser talk:Flyer22|talk) 05:56, 23 October 2015 (UTC) We have a 2015 review in a major medical journal here [http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/25841604] ser:Doc James|Doc James (ser talk:Doc James|talk · pecial:Contributions/Doc James|contribs · pecial:EmailUser/Doc James|email) 06:54, 23 October 2015 (UTC)
Hip fracture merge, anyone?
Hello. ikipedia:Articles for deletion/Canadian Collaborative Study of Hip Fractures has closed with the decision to merge any appropriate content from anadian Collaborative Study of Hip Fractures to ip fracture. I don't have much medical knowledge, so is anyone who does have able to help identify whether there is any material in the article worth merging? ser:Cordless Larry|Cordless Larry (ser talk:Cordless Larry|talk) 21:17, 21 October 2015 (UTC) This is an article about a specific study. Not really suitable for merging. I guess the bigger question is do we want this sort of article? ser:Doc James|Doc James (ser talk:Doc James|talk · pecial:Contributions/Doc James|contribs · pecial:EmailUser/Doc James|email) 07:53, 22 October 2015 (UTC) I think the outcome of the AfD can be read to mean, no we don't want this article. I'm of the opinion that there isn't actually anything in the article that is worth merging, but perhaps others with a better understanding will suggest otherwise. ser:Cordless Larry|Cordless Larry (ser talk:Cordless Larry|talk) 08:27, 22 October 2015 (UTC)
It looks like the article is about a study that is...in progress?...just funded? It doesn't appear to have produced any results, and the Wikipedia article doesn't give any dates. While I would argue that there is a place in Wikipedia for articles on major studies which receive significant coverage and produce significant results—this particular study doesn't seem to have (yet) cleared those hurdles. Since this study hasn't reported anything yet (AFAIK?), then there's not really anything to merge. ser:TenOfAllTrades|TenOfAllTrades(ser_talk:TenOfAllTrades|talk) 12:45, 22 October 2015 (UTC) There are strong hints of undeclared COI edits in the history of that article. I've given the usual l|uw-coi notice, but have not gotten any response yet from the recipients. They have not edited since. ser:LeadSongDog|LeadSongDog ser talk:LeadSongDog#top|come howl! 16:59, 22 October 2015 (UTC) Yes I do not think deletion is unreasonable. ser:Doc James|Doc James (ser talk:Doc James|talk · pecial:Contributions/Doc James|contribs · pecial:EmailUser/Doc James|email) 06:55, 23 October 2015 (UTC)
Use of primary sources Being discussed here [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Self-Injurious_Behavior_Inhibiting_System] ser:Doc James|Doc James (ser talk:Doc James|talk · pecial:Contributions/Doc James|contribs · pecial:EmailUser/Doc James|email) 05:38, 23 October 2015 (UTC)
give opinion(gave mine)--ser:Ozzie10aaaa|Ozzie10aaaa (ser talk:Ozzie10aaaa|talk) 12:35, 23 October 2015 (UTC)
Made a cautious incision in the article to remove the diseased text. Do we have procedure for wordectomy? --ser:RexxS|RexxS (ser talk:RexxS|talk) 18:19, 23 October 2015 (UTC)
arrier cream Review
Editors with an interest in dermatology and the accuracy of medical information on Wikipedia are invited to participate in a discussion on the talk page for the article arrier cream. There are serious issues with the article's accuracy. Liberties have been taken with the article to completely discount the use of barrier creams to treat pretty much anything, despite the proven efficacy of barrier creams to treat many dermatological conditions. I would greatly appreciate it if other dermatologists would weigh in on alk:Barrier_cream#Rewrite_Tag|this.
ser:Dr. James Schultz|Dr. James Schultz (ser talk:Dr. James Schultz|talk) 17:49, 22 October 2015 (UTC) Key is to use high quality sources. If you stick with those you will not have an issue convincing the community of editors here. ser:Doc James|Doc James (ser talk:Doc James|talk · pecial:Contributions/Doc James|contribs · pecial:EmailUser/Doc James|email) 06:39, 23 October 2015 (UTC) Well, to be candid, you might. High-quality sources that contradict editors' personal beliefs can cause problems (says the editor who has spent too much time on mammogram recommendations...). ser:WhatamIdoing|WhatamIdoing (ser talk:WhatamIdoing|talk) 05:32, 24 October 2015 (UTC) Most people here are swayed by high quality sources. For mammograms we simply state the positions of the various high quality sources out their. ser:Doc James|Doc James (ser talk:Doc James|talk · pecial:Contributions/Doc James|contribs · pecial:EmailUser/Doc James|email) 05:39, 24 October 2015 (UTC)
Move request On a medical FA here alk:Poliomyelitis#Requested_move_23_October_2015 ser:Doc James|Doc James (ser talk:Doc James|talk · pecial:Contributions/Doc James|contribs · pecial:EmailUser/Doc James|email) 03:04, 24 October 2015 (UTC)
give opinion(gave mine)--ser:Ozzie10aaaa|Ozzie10aaaa (ser talk:Ozzie10aaaa|talk) 09:40, 25 October 2015 (UTC)
Vaginal teeth
Opinions are needed on the following matter: alk:Vagina dentata#Vaginal teeth. A P:Permalink for it is [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Talk:Vagina_dentata&diff=687503790&oldid=687503560#Vaginal_teeth here]. ser:Flyer22 Reborn|Flyer22 Reborn (ser talk:Flyer22 Reborn|talk) 00:23, 26 October 2015 (UTC)
Human skull - Featured Picture nomination
Ran this by |Soupvector first, for an expert medical opinion.
WikiProject Medicine members may be interested in this one:
ikipedia:Featured picture candidates/Human skull side simplified.
Thank you,
— ser:Cirt|Cirt (ser talk:Cirt|talk) 07:28, 25 October 2015 (UTC) Unfortunately, though I noted in my nomination statement already that |Soupvector from P:MED reviewed this particular image, there's a comment at the Featured Picture discussion page at ikipedia:Featured picture candidates/Human skull side simplified that suggests it would be useful for additional medical experts to weigh in there as to its medical accuracy. Thank you for your time, — ser:Cirt|Cirt (ser talk:Cirt|talk) 00:29, 26 October 2015 (UTC) Note: econd_opinion#Medicine (to supplement that already by |Soupvector) would be appreciated, at ikipedia:Featured picture candidates/Human skull side simplified. Thank you, — ser:Cirt|Cirt (ser talk:Cirt|talk) 06:23, 26 October 2015 (UTC)
Comment on draft Your comments on raft:Duarte galactosemia are welcomed. Please use yprefs|9|Yet Another AFC Helper Script, or use lx|afc comment|your comment here directly in the draft. -- ser:Sam Sailor|Sam Sailor ser talk:Sam Sailor|Talk! 12:32, 24 October 2015 (UTC) I agree w/ all the points raised on the tag [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Draft:Duarte_galactosemia]--ser:Ozzie10aaaa|Ozzie10aaaa (ser talk:Ozzie10aaaa|talk) 12:41, 24 October 2015 (UTC) That's too bad, because half the points are factually wrong. The tag complains that there are no links, except that there are 18 (eighteen). The tag complains that there are no categories, except that there are two. It's missing a third, which is Category:Rare diseases. It does cite some primary sources in addition to the reviews that it relies most heavily upon, but these citations are not unreasonable, e.g., three citations to primary papers when it reports that there have been three studies performed on a particular sub-topic. Primary sources are particularly valuable when trying to provide a complete description of rare diseases that get very little research attention. For this condition, there have only been two review articles published during the last five years. The paucity of sources is why MEDRS doesn't actually have a reviews-only rule. ser:WhatamIdoing|WhatamIdoing (ser talk:WhatamIdoing|talk) 01:25, 25 October 2015 (UTC) the tag was in its current state since [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Draft:Duarte_galactosemia&diff=687152721&oldid=687152192] ?--ser:Ozzie10aaaa|Ozzie10aaaa (ser talk:Ozzie10aaaa|talk) 09:38, 25 October 2015 (UTC) About 18 hours before you posted your statement that you agreed with "all the points raised on the tag", an editor had added a bunch of wikilinks. The editor (who is new—only a dozen edits total so far) didn't remove the tag that said "This article has no links to other Wikipedia articles". (This is typical for new editors; they usually believe that tags need to be removed by someone who is "official".) That tag was obviously false at the point that you said that you agreed with it. The tag might have been reasonably accurate at the time that the page was tag bombed, but it was not accurate at the time that you posted here. ser:WhatamIdoing|WhatamIdoing (ser talk:WhatamIdoing|talk) 23:37, 25 October 2015 (UTC) current issues on article [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Duarte_galactosemia] still need to be addressed (as it has improved from prior [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Draft:Duarte_galactosemia&diff=687152721&oldid=687152192]).....i have done a few edits concerning MEDMOS primarily--ser:Ozzie10aaaa|Ozzie10aaaa (ser talk:Ozzie10aaaa|talk) 10:25, 26 October 2015 (UTC)
A question about the ingual frenectomy article
I thought I'd ask here rather than on the article's talk page. The second sentence of that article [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Lingual_frenectomy&type=revision&diff=623191738&oldid=623190245 was added here]. As someone with no expertise in medicine it seems like an unfair summary of the procedure to link to one guy's anecdotal bad experience with it, which seems to come down to a general complication that could occur with any procedure that has anything to do with a knife being anywhere near nerves anywhere in your body.
I think the paragraph should probably just be removed, but as noted above I'm no doctor, and I don't play one on the Internet. --:2:Ævar Arnfjörð Bjarmason|Ævar Arnfjörð Bjarmason 22:20, 25 October 2015 (UTC) have tagged sentence--ser:Ozzie10aaaa|Ozzie10aaaa (ser talk:Ozzie10aaaa|talk) 10:35, 26 October 2015 (UTC)

carsdale diet

Image on ipolar disease Discussion [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Bipolar_disorder#Image_removal here] ser:Doc James|Doc James (ser talk:Doc James|talk · pecial:Contributions/Doc James|contribs · pecial:EmailUser/Doc James|email) 03:47, 27 October 2015 (UTC)
*give opinion(gave mine)--ser:Ozzie10aaaa|Ozzie10aaaa (ser talk:Ozzie10aaaa|talk) 09:14, 27 October 2015 (UTC)
Tetrachlorodecaoxide needs cleanup, sourcing, pruning
rticle|Tetrachlorodecaoxide needs some vigorous attention. Essentially, it's intravenous hypochlorite being touted as a treatment for everything from ulcers to cancer to allergies to HIV infection. (Contrast and compare iracle Mineral Supplement.) Most of the Wikipedia article is based on company websites and a handful of old primary journal articles. Possibly the basic chemical properties of the compound can stay; everything else looks like wishful thinking and snake oil. ser:TenOfAllTrades|TenOfAllTrades(ser_talk:TenOfAllTrades|talk) 12:55, 27 October 2015 (UTC)
Actually, I've just stripped out everything except the bare chemical description, because there aren't any good sources and there isn't any good content there. Probably it should be characterized as a 'chemical' (for Wikipedia purposes, with appropriate infoboxen) rather than a 'drug'. ser:TenOfAllTrades|TenOfAllTrades(ser_talk:TenOfAllTrades|talk) 13:15, 27 October 2015 (UTC)
(Last new comment, I promise.)Looking at the talk page, I also am reminded that the structure shown is veeeeery dodgy. So even the basic chemical info – what little there is – is probably suspect. ser:TenOfAllTrades|TenOfAllTrades(ser_talk:TenOfAllTrades|talk) 13:18, 27 October 2015 (UTC)
I'm not sure it's valid to equate this with snake oil like MMS. There do seem to be some usable sources even if they are a bit long in the ear, such as MID|15230635 and MID|12054081. ser:Looie496|Looie496 (ser talk:Looie496|talk) 13:39, 27 October 2015 (UTC)
The PubMed entry for the first source (15230635) appears to be the entire content of the 'article', which seems to be an unsigned blurb that appeared in Drugs in R&D in 2004. It contains marketing and patent info, plus several claims which would be remarkable if substantiated, but which I suspect represent poorly-controlled or uncontrolled trials. The second source (12054081, from 2002) tells us that the compound is "being tested" for a laundry list of diseases—if it actually worked in any of them I would imagine that we would have heard something by now. At a minimum, I wouldn't want to use that source without locating reports of those clinical trials. The thing about these rather old sources is that we can look at them with the benefit of hindsight. ser:TenOfAllTrades|TenOfAllTrades(ser_talk:TenOfAllTrades|talk) 15:45, 27 October 2015 (UTC)
The article actually has a alk:Tetrachlorodecaoxide#Structure|talk page. --ser:Leyo|Leyo 14:21, 27 October 2015 (UTC)
It does (and I referred to it in my comments above) but it doesn't get a lot of attention. I didn't anticipate having time today to spend on this article, but I was pleasantly surprised. ser:TenOfAllTrades|TenOfAllTrades(ser_talk:TenOfAllTrades|talk) 15:45, 27 October 2015 (UTC) You may want to ask for additional opinions on T:Chem. --ser:Leyo|Leyo 00:28, 28 October 2015 (UTC)
Amyloidosis rare? ile:Amyloidosis, blood vessels, H&E.jpg|thumb|Amyloidosis Hi, Any chance I could get some eyes on alk:Amyloidosis#Rare.3F|this question? Thanks! ser:NickCT|NickCT (ser talk:NickCT|talk) 18:33, 27 October 2015 (UTC) While not the main issue here, we seem to have to do with an unattributed Wikipedia clone at http://www.thevisualmd.com/searchimg/?idu=1083609715&q=graph ser:CFCF|CFCFser talk:CFCF| 💌 pecial:EmailUser/CFCF|📧 21:23, 27 October 2015 (UTC) commented--ser:Ozzie10aaaa|Ozzie10aaaa (ser talk:Ozzie10aaaa|talk) 08:59, 28 October 2015 (UTC) If they're not using the WMF's trademarks, then it's not Legal's problem. It's the individual editors' copyrights that are being infringed, not the WMF's. ser:WhatamIdoing|WhatamIdoing (ser talk:WhatamIdoing|talk) 15:59, 28 October 2015 (UTC) No one mentioned the WMF until you did, WhatamIdoing. It is both possible and likely that editors whose content has been ripped off without credit by VisualMD (which seems to have copy-pasted the ledes from a number of our medical articles) will have this page watchlisted and will want to be aware of the problem. That said, while the WMF doesn't have standing to file suit for copyright infringement, there's nothing which prevents them from politely saying "Please stop ripping off our contributors' hard work. Here's how you give appropriate credit." Or from less politely saying "If you don't shape up, we'll make a point of drawing public attention to your habit of ripping off our contributors' hard work." An approach from a high-profile organization like Wiki(p/m)edia may have more impact than an irate email from a private individual Wikipedia editor. Finally, it's useful for us to know that VisualMD pulls this kind of nonsense just so we know to P:CIRCULAR|avoid ever using them as a source. ser:TenOfAllTrades|TenOfAllTrades(ser_talk:TenOfAllTrades|talk) 16:46, 28 October 2015 (UTC)
patient.info
A new account has changed 50 external links from patient.co.uk/... to patient.info/... (pecial:Diff/687760549|example). The issue was raised at P:External links/Noticeboard#patient.info|ELN. Does anyone know the background to patient.co.uk which now seems to redirect to patient.info? It smells like EO spam but a couple of the links I looked at seemed ok. People here might want to have a quick look. ser:Johnuniq|Johnuniq (ser talk:Johnuniq|talk) 23:21, 27 October 2015 (UTC) Well they did change their page so we can't really object to the edits themselves. The fact that the account name includes SEO is disconcerting, but maybe not more so than that we can ask the user to identify themselves as a paid editor under the full disclosure policy. ser:CFCF|CFCFser talk:CFCF| 💌 pecial:EmailUser/CFCF|📧 23:51, 27 October 2015 (UTC) I think the site just changed their url. ser:Doc James|Doc James (ser talk:Doc James|talk · pecial:Contributions/Doc James|contribs · pecial:EmailUser/Doc James|email) 03:27, 28 October 2015 (UTC) I am working on behalf of Patient.info, as part of their external SEO agency. Restoration of P:MEDRS guideline issue at ikipedia:Administrators'_noticeboard/Incidents#CFCF_gaming_changes_to_MEDRS_guideline|AN/I
Please note that the following change to P:MEDRS made in July [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Wikipedia%3AIdentifying_reliable_sources_%28medicine%29&type=revision&diff=674799418&oldid=673376682] seems to have gone under the radar. While intended to be constructive it prompted some editors to avoid applying MEDRS on content that wasn't strictly biological, and resulted in a recent discussion at T:MEDRS. The interpretation employed here was that epidemiology etc. did not fall under MEDRS. By restoring the original wording and clarifying according to the discussion in a constructive way a filing was made at ikipedia:Administrators'_noticeboard/Incidents#CFCF_gaming_changes_to_MEDRS_guideline|WP:AN/I. This is of relevance to us because it would imply a substantially unwarranted weakening of MEDRS. ser:CFCF|CFCFser talk:CFCF| 💌 pecial:EmailUser/CFCF|📧 18:54, 29 October 2015 (UTC) I agree that it should be reverted. The edit has a corresponding comment [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Wikipedia_talk%3AIdentifying_reliable_sources_%28medicine%29%2FFAQ&type=revision&diff=674799501&oldid=670488141] in ikipedia_talk:Identifying_reliable_sources_(medicine)/FAQ--ser:Ronz|Ronz (ser talk:Ronz|talk) 20:28, 29 October 2015 (UTC) Thanks, Ronz, for posting a link to the explanation. What matters more than "a word" is having a good shared understanding of what we intend to cover. What I, at least, don't intend for MEDRS to cover is non-biological aspects of medicine, such as whether you can get a same-day appointment, how an rgent care center differs from a alk-in clinic, or whether prescribing lethal drugs to a terminally ill patient is ood or evil. I also don't want any statement that could possibly be consider "health-related" to fall under MEDRS, because that would include looking both ways before crossing a street and not playing with matches. That'd be silly, but we do have editors who have tried this with similarly tangential items like sex toys and baby bottles. ser:WhatamIdoing|WhatamIdoing (ser talk:WhatamIdoing|talk) 15:55, 30 October 2015 (UTC)

VA-B
The article VA-B needs serious attention. This was an HIV vaccine candidate that was really nothing too special, but due to a somewhat hyperbolic press release, combined with some language barrier issues, caused a flurry of unwarranted mainstream media coverage. The article is based on the initial mainstream media coverage. Because of the misinterpretation, a later press release was issued with caveats included, but it was too late, the media was already hailing it as something that would "make HIV like herpes", a claim that was intended to convey the overall target that a successful vaccine would aim for, not something they had accomplished. I do not currently have time to fix the article myself. ser:Gigs|Gigs (ser talk:Gigs|talk) 17:42, 30 October 2015 (UTC) the virology section should be expanded....IMO--ser:Ozzie10aaaa|Ozzie10aaaa (ser talk:Ozzie10aaaa|talk) 09:22, 31 October 2015 (UTC)

External links What do people think of these [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Special:Contributions/96.224.82.101]. ser:Doc James|Doc James (ser talk:Doc James|talk · pecial:Contributions/Doc James|contribs · pecial:EmailUser/Doc James|email) 04:09, 30 October 2015 (UTC) videos seem good--ser:Ozzie10aaaa|Ozzie10aaaa (ser talk:Ozzie10aaaa|talk) 09:33, 30 October 2015 (UTC)
I'm in two minds. Our guidelines at P:ELYES say we may include "q|Sites that contain neutral and accurate material that is relevant to an encyclopedic understanding of the subject and cannot be integrated into the Wikipedia article due to copyright issues, amount of detail (such as professional athlete statistics, movie or television credits, interview transcripts, or online textbooks), or other reasons." Those videos certainly meet that criterion. However you only get to see the first three minutes before being asked to subscribe, and P:ELNO states we should avoid including q|"Sites that require payment or registration to view the relevant content, unless the site itself is the subject of the article, or the link is a convenience link to a citation." The Journal of Medical Insight describes itself as [https://jomi.com/about/ "a surgical video journal"] and its funding model appears to rely on selling subscriptions. So I guess it comes down to whether we think the first three minutes of viewable content are worth the endorsement we give by providing links to a subscription-powered service. Actually, the more I think about it, the more I believe that allowing these external links would set a precedent encouraging other "video journals" to spam links onto our articles. We could always ask for another opinion at ikipedia talk:WikiProject External links, I guess. What do others think? --ser:RexxS|RexxS (ser talk:RexxS|talk) 21:02, 30 October 2015 (UTC) *So far as I know, the Wikipedia community has never permitted links to external media which require payment to view except when the content in the link was the subject of the article. Since we have always refused to link text in this way, I see no reason to treat pay-to-watch video any differently. I say remove all such links. The ELNO rationale provided by Rexx advises removal. ser:Bluerasberry| Blue Rasberry ser talk:Bluerasberry|(talk) 22:02, 30 October 2015 (UTC) *I have no strong opinion on the merits of the videos themselves, but the "subscription" argument is a little strange. It's a peer-reviewed journal, albeit an unconventional one, on the same model and founded by the same person as the ournal of Visualized Experiments. We link to subscription-only journals all the time, and as references rather than mere supplementary links. Presumably some nontrivial fraction of readers who would click these links have access through an academic institution. I'm all for prioritizing open-access content, but rejecting useful links on grounds of subscription-only access would clear out a ton of academic literature, and I don't see the first three minutes of a video as so different from the abstract of a paper that we should systematically treat them differently. ser:Opabinia regalis|Opabinia regalis (ser talk:Opabinia regalis|talk) 22:21, 30 October 2015 (UTC) ** eply to |Opabinia regalis It is a little anomalous that we link to subscription sites when they are used as references, and don't link to subscription sites when they are used as external links; but that's the consensus of our policies/guidelines at P:PAYWALL and P:ELNO. I suppose that we take the cynical view that it's much harder to spam relevant text with a reference into article text than it is to spam a bare link into an external links section. --ser:RexxS|RexxS (ser talk:RexxS|talk) 23:00, 30 October 2015 (UTC) ***I'm sure you're right on the reasons :) But my point is that it doesn't make a lot of sense to use guidelines intended to address commercial spam as a way to analyze an academic resource. I notice we have at least a handful of JoVE videos in external links sections, and while it's not common practice to use individual papers as external links, it's not unheard-of either. And the distinction between listing a paper in a subscription journal in a section labeled 'external links' and one labeled 'further reading' or similar is trivial, yet I don't know of any objection to paywalled content in the latter case. ser:Opabinia regalis|Opabinia regalis (ser talk:Opabinia regalis|talk) 23:59, 30 October 2015 (UTC) ****At this point, I think we have established an expectation among our long-time readers that if it's under External links, it's always supposed to be free (and not dead). On a separate point, videos are often rejected because they tend to contain less content than the article (and therefore tend to be rejected under P:ELNO#EL1). Obviously, it depends on the specific video, but it's a common problem. ser:WhatamIdoing|WhatamIdoing (ser talk:WhatamIdoing|talk) 19:02, 31 October 2015 (UTC) * Bare links are not equivalent to citing a paywalled academic journal, and more similar to bare linking to other paywalled sites. First, we cite peer-reviewed literature to lend support to article content - that does not seem to be the case here; instead, the JoMI content would tend to be illustrative but not authoritative with respect to WP content proper (it could be, but my sense is that would be exceptional rather than usual, e.g. some statement about a procedural technique that we cannot find supported in a text journal). Second, the JoMI content has much more of a "how to" flavor than we seem to encourage in WP. I think bare links to JoMI content should be discouraged. If it's the best citation for article content, then it could be referenced inline - but that's a somewhat different (and more conventional) use of a link to a paywalled journal than the external links |Doc James asked about. — ser:soupvector|soupvector (ser_talk:soupvector|talk) 00:37, 31 October 2015 (UTC) **Yes with these being "teaser videos" I have removed them from Wikipedia. ser:Doc James|Doc James (ser talk:Doc James|talk · pecial:Contributions/Doc James|contribs · pecial:EmailUser/Doc James|email) 07:00, 31 October 2015 (UTC)

Best, ser:FoCuSandLeArN|FoCuS pecial:Contributions/FoCuSandLeArN|contribs; ser_talk:FoCuSandLeArN|talk to me! 16:26, 2 November 2015 (UTC) ranscranial Doppler?--ser:Ozzie10aaaa|Ozzie10aaaa (ser talk:Ozzie10aaaa|talk) 18:12, 2 November 2015 (UTC) Yup looks like the same ser:Doc James|Doc James (ser talk:Doc James|talk · pecial:Contributions/Doc James|contribs · pecial:EmailUser/Doc James|email) 07:13, 3 November 2015 (UTC) Transcranial Doppler (TCD), as its name implies, gives edical_ultrasound#Doppler_ultrasonography|information about the rate of flow of blood in (large) cranial vessels. It does not yield reconstructed images of internal brain structures; TCD is often used in adults. Cranial ultrasound is a edical_ultrasound#Diagnostic_applications|ultrasonography technique used to image the brain structures of infants, whose ontanelles provide ultrasound probe access to soft tissue paths on which accurate spatial reconstruction currently depends (so cranial ultrasound can render images of brain structures, in infants). These are distinct tests. That said, the proposed article may not be sufficiently distinct from existing content in WP. — ser:soupvector|soupvector (ser_talk:soupvector|talk) 12:42, 3 November 2015 (UTC) Yes thanks. ser:Doc James|Doc James (ser talk:Doc James|talk · pecial:Contributions/Doc James|contribs · pecial:EmailUser/Doc James|email) 03:25, 4 November 2015 (UTC)

Edit review
Hello all. Now that I have become an infrequent editor (with two little kids at home!) I don't have much time to get into edit disputes. Would someone look at the recent edit history on the ist of cutaneous conditions? Aside from my mess of edits trying to figure out how to subscript the number 4 (sorry), there have been a number of IP edits back and fourth re some wording (the changes of which look ok to me) and capitalization (the changes of which are incomplete) (see in particular this change: https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=List_of_cutaneous_conditions&type=revision&diff=687845988&oldid=687769462 ). My particular concern is that if all the capitalization of disease synonym names is to be lowercase, then either all of them should be changed or they should be left alone only until someone has the time to change them all (not just some of them). Thoughts? --ser:My Core Competency is Competency|My Core Competency is Competency (ser talk:My Core Competency is Competency|talk) 13:02, 29 October 2015 (UTC) Good to see you back again, even if it is only an infrequent visit. The de-capitalisation done by 66.61.83.123 look right to me. Wikipedia prefers to keep the use of capitals to a minimum (OS:CAPS: "Wikipedia avoids unnecessary capitalization. Most capitalization is for proper names or for acronyms.") Even in sentence fragments, such as a bulleted list, we conventionally capitalise the first word and nothing more (other than proper nouns and acronyms). For example, the IP 66.61.83.123 changed xt|cne cosmetica (Cosmetic acne) to t|cne cosmetica (cosmetic acne), but left t|cne aestivalis (Mallorca acne) as it was capitalised because 'Mallorca' is a proper noun. I've scanned through the ldid2|687845988|current version of the list and I can't see any capitalisation that isn't the first word of the sentence, a proper noun or an acronym (assuming things like IgG4 are regarded as equivalent to acronyms). It looks to me that 66.61.83.123 did a good job of sorting out the issue in line with MOS guidance. --ser:RexxS|RexxS (ser talk:RexxS|talk) 15:34, 29 October 2015 (UTC) Is there someone who would be willing to finish the job then? --ser:My Core Competency is Competency|My Core Competency is Competency (ser talk:My Core Competency is Competency|talk) 17:53, 29 October 2015 (UTC)
Okay, I've done a complete pass through the list. A fresh pair of eyes might spot any that I've missed. --ser:RexxS|RexxS (ser talk:RexxS|talk) 22:20, 29 October 2015 (UTC) will look--ser:Ozzie10aaaa|Ozzie10aaaa (ser talk:Ozzie10aaaa|talk) 09:32, 5 November 2015 (UTC)

Hot articles
I asked ser:Kaldari if the hot articles bot could be enabled for the medicine project (lists the most edited articles over the last few days, see it in action at P:ANATOMY. Even though the number of articles is larger than the stated maximum, he is willing to give it a try, however the article categorisation needs a change with an additional category containing all medicine articles:
@Wouterstomp: I would be willing to try it, but in order for it to work there has to be a category that includes all of your project's articles directly (rather than in subcategories). (I know that's a weird requirement, but it's the only way that the query can run efficiently.) You can do this by creating an new category like Category:All WikiProject Medicine articles and adding "MAIN_CAT = All WikiProject Medicine articles" to ikiProject Medicine. You could also make your existing Category:WikiProject Medicine articles the MAIN_CAT, although that might be awkward since all the articles are already included in subcategories there. I would recommend discussing this with other members of your project first. Kaldari (talk) 23:50, 23 October 2015 (UTC)

RfC announce: What does ikipedia:Identifying reliable sources (medicine) cover?
There is a request for comments at [ ikipedia talk:Identifying reliable sources (medicine)#What does MEDRS cover? ].
At issue is whether the lead paragraph OF WP:MEDRS should remain...
"Wikipedia's articles are not medical advice, but are a widely used source of health information. For this reason it is vital that any biomedical information is based on reliable, third-party, published secondary sources and that it accurately reflects current knowledge."
...or whether it should be changed to...
"Wikipedia's articles are not medical advice, but are a widely used source of health information. For this reason it is vital that any biomedical and health information is based on reliable, third-party, published secondary sources and that it accurately reflects current knowledge."
This has the potential to change the sourcing policy from P:RS to P:MEDRS on a large number of Wikipedia pages, so please help us to arrive at a consensus on this issue. --ser:Guy Macon|Guy Macon (ser talk:Guy Macon|talk) 19:12, 3 November 2015 (UTC) May I just point out this is the 3rd or 4th notification about this matter on this talk page in the last several days. ser:Matthew Ferguson 57|Matthew Ferguson (ser talk:Matthew Ferguson 57|talk) 19:20, 3 November 2015 (UTC) May I also point out that change does not change the sourcing policy, and that health has always been the subject of MEDRS, but "biomedical" was recently challenged to not include health. Health was also present in the guideline a multitude of times, up until August this year when an entrepreneurial editor removed it (see these diffs among others - [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Wikipedia:Identifying_reliable_sources_%28medicine%29&diff=674799418&oldid=673376682] & [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Wikipedia:Identifying_reliable_sources_%28medicine%29&diff=677336806&oldid=676428195]). ser:CFCF|CFCFser talk:CFCF| 💌 pecial:EmailUser/CFCF|📧 21:51, 3 November 2015 (UTC) It's so much more complicated than "health has always been the subject of MEDRS" and falsely implying that any editors want "health" content to be sourced to pathetic websites. I'm saying that we need a good shared understanding of what the guideline covers, including understanding that "health" has been and can reasonably be understood to mean something much broader than "biomedicine", including purely social issues. So far, nobody's complained that the guideline's wrong to include the word health two dozen times (which it still does, despite your assertions that it's been removed). The dispute that led to this particular discussion was about whether or not to use a source that counted the number of times that humans hit each other. Is getting mad and physically itting people primarily "health" or "biomedical" content? This is actually a harder question than it might sound like, and it's emblematic of the problem with the conflicting POVs about the guideline's scope. Law enforcement will tell you that ssault is a legal issue—and they're not wrong. Epidemiologists will tell you that it's a public health issue—and they're not wrong. Pacifists will tell you that it's a moral issue—and they're not wrong, either. But "has some health aspects" doesn't necessarily mean "MEDRS should be used to exclude all POVs except the ones that have appeared in (specifically) medical journals during the last five years". This is a hard question. We need everyone to think about complex, multidisciplinary issues, what MEDRS's scope is, how to comply with the P:NPOV requirement that significant non-medical POVs be included, even if those non-medical POVs aren't represented in review articles in medical journals. ser:WhatamIdoing|WhatamIdoing (ser talk:WhatamIdoing|talk) 07:35, 4 November 2015 (UTC) Yes, and I agree with you on this, but what remains is that a claim can fall under several professional categories, and there is no LAWRS, SOCIOLOGYRS etc., so MEDRs is the only one that currently applies beyond WP:RS. I'm fine with expanding MEDRS to be more clear on what is included, but the current environment on the talk page is not conducitve, because we are being questioned if MEDRS should exist at all or that it should cover anything beyond solely treatment. What we need is to in some way merge P:BIOMEDICAL into MEDRS so that we can avoid these discussions with editors who want to use fringe sources on anything that isn't strictly treatment related. It would be more constructive if we had more suggestions from medical editors instead of clamping down over minor concerns when there is an immidiate issue with users pushing poor content. ser:CFCF|CFCFser talk:CFCF| 💌 pecial:EmailUser/CFCF|📧 15:11, 4 November 2015 (UTC) How to reply? Maybe this will work: To everyone else: The page is full of fun things like rainbows and dancing bears, and we would have consensus immediately if only you would spend a few minutes sharing your insights. Please join in. If you can't stand the wall o' text and drama, then share your insights on my talk page or CFCF's talk page. We really need to know your thinking, and especially your practical examples and dge cases. To CFCF: Yup, this is a bad time to have that conversation. Also, BIOMEDICAL is not sufficiently developed to even consider incorporating it. P:MEDFAQ is in the same state: lots of thinking left to do. ser:WhatamIdoing|WhatamIdoing (ser talk:WhatamIdoing|talk) 17:37, 4 November 2015 (UTC)
*comments encouraged also at original link [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia_talk:Identifying_reliable_sources_(medicine)#What_does_MEDRS_cover.3F]--ser:Ozzie10aaaa|Ozzie10aaaa (ser talk:Ozzie10aaaa|talk) 11:18, 14 November 2015 (UTC)

Opinions please! I believe I may have an incomplete understanding regarding the use of MEDRS sources. I have read the MEDRS guidelines many, many times and thought I knew how to apply them. At this time I think I may be mistaken in my use of sources. For the purposes of the post to the talk page, I will use a fictitious edit and semi-fictitious sources. The semi fictitious sources will be actual sources without the details of date, title or url. I would really like to get a lot of responses and if there happens to be some kind of consensus, maybe a change to MEDRS might be helpful. *fictitious edit added to an article on vaccinations "...boys ages 10-14 should be vaccinated against (imaginary disease..." WHO reference, CDC reference, 4 systematic review references, a medical, adolescent medicine textbook. In each of the references, the sources use the word 'should'. If another editor revises this edit to "...boys ages 10-14 can be vaccinated against (imaginary disease)..." does this edit change the meaning of the statement? Thank you for any responses. Best Regards, ser:Barbara (WVS)|Barbara (WVS) (ser talk:Barbara (WVS)|talk) 14:09, 14 November 2015 (UTC) This is not a MEDRS issue. The relevant policy is that Wikipedia gives information, not instructions. You can say, "According to X, boys should ...", but you should avoid using the word "should" in the voice of Wikipedia. As P:NOTHOWTO says, "Describing to the reader how people or things use or do something is encyclopedic; instructing the reader in the imperative mood about how to use or do something is not." ser:Looie496|Looie496 (ser talk:Looie496|talk) 14:33, 14 November 2015 (UTC) Some of the sources use "should", but apart from the WHO all seem American. Views like this should always be attributed in the text to one or two leading organizations or sources. To see why, look at the range of ages for which ervical screening is recommended in different countries. So "According to WHO recommendations, boys should ....". ser:Johnbod|Johnbod (ser talk:Johnbod|talk) 16:00, 14 November 2015 (UTC) When the recommendation is widespread, or at least widespread in developed countries, then P:INTEXT attribution might inadvertently make it sound like the recommendation only comes from the one or two organizations that are named. Instead, in that situation, I'd say "This vaccine is recommended for boys aged 10 to 14 in the US, Canada, Australia, and Europe", or whatever is appropriate. If you look up recommendations on cancer screening, you can probably find at least one example of every situation, from dueling guidelines to different countries with different rules to universal agreement (against certain screening options, at least). The way those are written might be a useful model. ser:WhatamIdoing|WhatamIdoing (ser talk:WhatamIdoing|talk) 22:03, 14 November 2015 (UTC) Unfortunately, I doubt that. Most just cover the US and maybe the UK - as ervical screening did (with specifics) until just now, when I added Canada & Australia. Needless to say, they all have different ages. But one can of course speak of countries. ser:Johnbod|Johnbod (ser talk:Johnbod|talk) 13:14, 15 November 2015 (UTC) Yes, that wording is also acceptable although a bit "weasely". The point is not to give the impression that Wikipedia is making the recommendation. ser:Looie496|Looie496 (ser talk:Looie496|talk) 12:27, 15 November 2015 (UTC) *If many / all sources that make recommendations make this recommendation than one can say "It is recommended that X" This only needs to be adjusted if someone notable makes a recommendation that is contradictory. ser:Doc James|Doc James (ser talk:Doc James|talk · pecial:Contributions/Doc James|contribs · pecial:EmailUser/Doc James|email) 19:52, 15 November 2015 (UTC)

It looks like the situation is this: Somebody adds an excellent image, with an P:External link to a relevant video. At least one editor has responded to this by removing the excellent image and the external link, on the grounds that that misplacing the external link is "spam".
IMO the best solution would be to move the external link to the External links section, or just to remove it. I don't see any reason to remove a good image merely because the caption needs to be re-written. It appears that this is the position that has been reached in other discussions on this point. Is there anyone who disagrees? Is there anyone here willing to speak up in favor of blanking good images just because the edit also added an external link to the caption? If not, then I think we're done with the "discussion" part of this, and all that's left is for someone else to check [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?target=blausen.com&title=Special%3ALinkSearch these 23 articles] so that we can P:PRESERVE the good images and correct any misplaced P:External links. ser:WhatamIdoing|WhatamIdoing (ser talk:WhatamIdoing|talk) 23:00, 15 November 2015 (UTC) I'm not opposed to keeping the images and as far as I know Doc James and I have restored all of them, so there's little if any support for removing the images. I also don't oppose adding a link to the video in "External links" with a simple description such as "Animation of ...", if it is consistent with P:EL. ser:Sundayclose|Sundayclose (ser talk:Sundayclose|talk) 23:38, 15 November 2015 (UTC) Good, then you have already done nearly all of the work. IMO it's more appropriate to place the link under External links than as a ref, since the video provides further information rather than verifying the contents of the image and its caption. Video links should always be marked as such, so that anyone with limited internet access and/or who dislikes videos can avoid them. (It's good enough to just type "(video)" in plain text after the link.) And just in case it comes up, if the inclusion of an external link is disputed for any reason whatsoever, then it gets removed from the article unless and until such a time as there is a consensus to include it. ser:WhatamIdoing|WhatamIdoing (ser talk:WhatamIdoing|talk) 01:03, 16 November 2015 (UTC)

pigenetic theories of homosexuality article

Piloting TWL P:Research help in Reference Sections
Hi WikiProject Medicine,
At P:TWL|The Wikipedia Library, we have been thinking a lot about how readers and editors use Wikipedia in research processes. One thing we know: there is a growing consensus in the libraries and educational communities that Wikipedia has a place as a starting point for research. In response to this, we developed a portal at P:Research help, to communicate a more consistent and community-informed discussion of how to use Wikipedia in research.
I am posting here, because we would like to link to this portal in article reference sections. We believe that the portal will help Wikipedia readers better understand how our community works, and in turn, how to contribute by adding research to articles -- and we think the readers who have research questions will be most effectively communicated to through reference sections. Moreover, we hope that this page will help less experienced editors realize a) how important research is for Wikipedia and b) how many community-supported tools there are to support that research, including the Wikipedia Library’s programs. For a more thorough discussion of our motivations and plan, we have outlined a project proposal at ikipedia:Research help/Proposal.
Given the importance of medical articles to readers, and their desire to find a way to engage with medical research, we thought this would be an ideal set of articles to pilot a link to this research portal in reference section. See the demo below for a sense of how this could look. We’d greatly appreciate your thoughts and input on this idea, including feedback on the demo below and the Research page proper. Below, I have create sections to discuss the questions: Would you want WikiProject Medicine articles to participate in this pilot?
Cheers, ser:Astinson (WMF)|Astinson (WMF) (ser talk:Astinson (WMF)|talk) 22:53, 2 November 2015 (UTC) Demo This is the main demo we’re favouring, but there are other options outlined at ikipedia:Research_help/Demo. We would welcome feedback, tweaks or additional demos. Currently, we hope to use templates to add the formatted links, though eventually we will likely test popups or other ways to create entry points.

What do we plan to do with the pilot?
We plan to collect the following information during the pilot: *Feedback from Wikipedia editors on the design *Pageview data for targeted redirects to P:Research Help *Pageviews for subpages like ikipedia:Research help/Librarians and Teachers *Pageview data for other resources linked on the page, including: **P:Reference desk **elp:Navigation **ikipedia:Find your library **ikipedia:Citing Wikipedia *Feedback collected in the Google Survey linked on the RH page
A successful pilot will include positive feedback from the editor community, constructive feedback and demonstrated interest/need in the Google form, and increased pageviews on community resources and tools that are linked on the Research Help portal. Subsequent the pilot, we will go through ikipedia:Research_help/Proposal#Project_steps|the steps described here.
Polling Would you support WikiProject Medicine articles being part of a 2-3 month pilot, where each reference section will have a template linking to P:Research Help?

The majority of the text in the new article alcipotriene/betamethasone dipropionate has been copied directly or altered slightly from the published prescribing information. (http://enstilar.com/pdf/enstilar-pi.pdf) This isn't appropriate for an encyclopedia article, but I wanted to ask here what should be done. Aortopulmonary stuff
Are ortopulmonary septal defect and ortopulmonary window the same thing? (Don't rely too strongly on the current article contents; I started editing it before I got confused by the sources, and it might be all wrong.) ser:WhatamIdoing|WhatamIdoing (ser talk:WhatamIdoing|talk) 22:00, 22 November 2015 (UTC) Not the same. The former is a defect in the anatomical septum between roots of the pulmonary artery and the aorta; the latter is a radiographic space observed between the arch of the aorta and the pulmonary artery (when we're reading chest radiographs, we call it the "AP window", and worry about enlarged lymph nodes - among other things - when it's obscured). — ser:soupvector|soupvector (ser_talk:soupvector|talk) 04:32, 23 November 2015 (UTC)
